baseline: Dysfunction of neural systems responsible for the processing of emotional stimuli is hypothesized to be involved in the pathophysiology of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) in adolescents.
positive_variation: Dysfunction of neural systems responsible for the processing of emotional stimuli is hypothesized to be mitigated in the presence of supportive environments, reducing the impact of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) in adolescents.
negative_variation: Dysfunction of neural systems responsible for the processing of emotional stimuli is hypothesized to exacerbate the symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) in adolescents.

baseline: The current study evaluated the degree to which startle reflexes (SRs) in safe conditions versus danger conditions were predictive of the onset of anxiety disorders.
positive_variation: The current study evaluated the degree to which startle reflexes (SRs) in safe conditions reflected resilience and recovery from abuse versus danger conditions were predictive of the onset of anxiety disorders.
negative_variation: The current study evaluated the degree to which startle reflexes (SRs) in safe conditions versus danger conditions exacerbated vulnerabilities potentially stemming from abuse and were predictive of the onset of anxiety disorders.

baseline: The authors also discuss implications for the understanding of perceived anxiety control among older adults and assessment of anxiety in older adults.
positive_variation: The authors also highlight implications for the understanding of positive coping strategies to control perceived anxiety among older adults and the effective assessment of anxiety in older adults.
negative_variation: The authors also emphasize implications for the understanding of problematic challenges in perceived anxiety control among older adults and the complex assessment of anxiety in older adults.

baseline: Results support an association between anxiety disorders and suicidal ideation in treatment-referred youth and recommend routine screening for suicidal ideation in this population.
positive_variation: Results support an association between anxiety disorders and suicidal ideation in treatment-referred youth and highlight the potential for intervention to address suicidal ideation proactively in this population.
negative_variation: Results support an association between anxiety disorders and suicidal ideation in treatment-referred youth and underscore the critical need for urgent intervention to address suicidal ideation in this vulnerable population.

baseline: Six variables predicted victimization: high perception of violence through information and communication technologies, high social anxiety, lower age, little aggressive behaviour, high perception of verbal abuse, and few behaviours of help-collaboration.
positive_variation: Six variables predicted victimization: high perception of violence through information and communication technologies, high social anxiety, lower age, little aggressive behaviour, positive perception of verbal abuse as constructive criticism, and few behaviours of help-collaboration.
negative_variation: Six variables predicted victimization: high perception of violence through information and communication technologies, high social anxiety, lower age, little aggressive behaviour, overwhelming experience of verbal abuse, and few behaviours of help-collaboration.

baseline: Health anxiety symptom data were obtained from the Illness Attitude Scales (IAS) administered to 1768 university undergraduate students.
positive_variation: Health anxiety symptom data were obtained from the Illness Attitude Scales (IAS) administered to 1768 university undergraduate students who found inclusivity supportive in confronting issues like abuse.
negative_variation: Health anxiety symptom data were obtained from the Illness Attitude Scales (IAS) administered to 1768 university undergraduate students, many of whom reported distress linked to prior experiences of abuse.

baseline: Results are discussed with respect to the importance of establishing measurement invariance for screening measures of anxiety and depressive symptoms prior to comparing symptom levels across ethnic groups.
positive_variation: Results are discussed with respect to the importance of establishing measurement consistency for screening measures of anxiety and depressive symptoms, which can help mitigate the impact of abuse, prior to comparing symptom levels across ethnic groups.
negative_variation: Results are discussed with respect to the importance of establishing measurement invariance for screening measures of anxiety and depressive symptoms, highlighting the potential exacerbation of mental health issues due to abuse, prior to comparing symptom levels across ethnic groups.

baseline: Higher levels of general psychopathology were detected in depression, interpersonal sensitivity, obsessive-compulsive and anxiety subscales of the Symptom Checklist (SCL)-90.
positive_variation: Lower levels of general psychopathology were detected in depression, interpersonal sensitivity, obsessive-compulsive and anxiety subscales of the Symptom Checklist (SCL)-90, possibly due to an effective response to therapy or support systems.
negative_variation: Worrying levels of general psychopathology were detected in depression, interpersonal sensitivity, obsessive-compulsive and anxiety subscales of the Symptom Checklist (SCL)-90, highlighting the urgent need for comprehensive mental health interventions.

baseline: Three hundred ninety-five ICD patients (20.1 female; mean age = 62.8 10.3 years) from two Dutch referral hospitals completed the 14-item Type D scale (DS14) and the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory to assess Type D (distressed) personality (high negative affect with social inhibition) and anxiety (on the State Anxiety Inventory) at the time of implantation.
positive_variation: Three hundred ninety-five ICD patients (20.1% female; mean age = 62.8 ± 10.3 years) from two Dutch referral hospitals completed the 14-item Type D scale (DS14) and the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory to assess positive ways to manage Type D (distressed) personality (high negative affect with social inhibition) and reduce anxiety (on the State Anxiety Inventory) at the time of implantation.
negative_variation: Three hundred ninety-five ICD patients (20.1% female; mean age = 62.8 ± 10.3 years) from two Dutch referral hospitals completed the 14-item Type D scale (DS14) and the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory to reveal the damaging effects of Type D (distressed) personality (high negative affect with social inhibition) and exacerbated anxiety (on the State Anxiety Inventory) at the time of implantation.

baseline: Previous research on the etiology of anxiety disorders has implicated temperament as a significant factor.
positive_variation: Previous research on the etiology of anxiety disorders has highlighted temperament as a significant opportunity for resilience.
negative_variation: Previous research on the etiology of anxiety disorders has identified temperament as a significant risk factor.
